newsitem.title: USA: Oil prices lead commodity indexes lower.
newsitem.headline: Oil prices lead commodity indexes lower.

text.p: Oil prices fell Tuesday as traders bet that low inventories of heating oil were finally starting to rise ahead of winter. Coffee and silver prices also fell.
The Knight Ridder Commodity Research Bureau index of 17 futures prices ended 2.22 points lower at 241.11.
Heating oil prices tumbled on expectations the American Petroleum Institute (API) would show a build-up in stocks of heating oil and diesel fuels in weekly oil inventory data.

Heating oil for November delivery fell 1.63 cents to 69.83 cents a gallon at the New York Mercantile Exchange. November unleaded gasoline fell 1.20 cents to 69.10 cents a gallon and December crude oil lost 51 cents to $24.34 a barrel.

Record low heating oil inventories had sent heating oil and crude prices to new post-Gulf War highs this month, but the belief that heating oil stocks were being replenished has been pushing oil prices lower the past two weeks.

"There has been a change in psychology in the market with the effort by refiners to build stocks," said ING Derivatives analyst Tom Bentz. "Heat was hit because people are expecting the stats to show a bearish build."
After the close of trading, the API said that distillate stocks grew 3.6 million barrels in the week ended Oct. 25, a bigger buildup than the 1 million- to 3 million-barrel rise traders had expected.

Crude stocks fell 2.5 million barrels compared with an expected drop of up to 2 million barrels. Gasoline stocks fell 3.8 million barrels, a sharper drop than the expected decline of up to 3 million barrels.
Coffee futures closed lower in volatile trading as speculators ignored record low warehouse stocks and instead concentrated on central and South American supplies expected to arrive soon.
December coffee fell 2.75 cents to 116.35 cents a pound at the Coffee Sugar and Cocoa Exchange after trading as high as 123 cents a pound during the day, the highest in a month.

On Monday the exchange reported warehouse stocks of coffee suitable for delivery against futures fell 4,036 132-pound bags in the week ended Oct. 25 to just 1,547 bags, the lowest since the exchange began tracking inventories in 1980.
But traders said new crop from Colombia should start to flow soon into the market following the end of a 12-day truckers' strike on Thursday.
And many Central American countries, which have had difficulty getting their beans to port due to flooding and heavy rains, should begin exporting in coming weeks.
"We are eventually going to see a buildup in stocks," said Dean Witter analyst Steve Platt. "It seems to undercut each rally attempt."
Precious metals also fell sharply as the rally in the stock and bond markets drew money from other investments.
December silver at the COMEX division of the New York Mercantile Exchange fell 11 cents to $4.82 an ounce after hitting $4.81, the lowest price since late 1994.
December gold lost $3 to $381.60 an ounce.
The rally in stock and bond markets after wage and consumer confidence data pointed to tame inflation discouraged buying in precious metals, traditionally an inflation hedge for investors.
"The breakout in the U.S. 30-year bond futures to multi-month highs encouraged more fund selling," Friedberg Mercantile Group's Toronto-based trader Jeff Kowal said.
Unconfirmed rumours of further European central bank selling of gold reserves as countries sought to meet the 1999 single-currency criteria also depressed sentiment, traders said.
